parts: Name this opera by Pietro Mascagni which narrates the story of Lola, Santuzza, and the men who duel over them. It is based on a short story by Giovanni Verga.

Like Pagliacci, with which it is often paired, Cavalleria rusticana belongs to this genre of Italian opera which focuses on depicting realistic emotions and characters. Verdi is often considered the supreme composer of it.
This man, Lucia's son, is the male lead of Cavalleria rusticana. He bites his rival Alfio's ear to instigate a fight to the death, which he then loses.

Identify this form of spectroscopy in which carbonyl groups appear around 1700 wavenumbers and alcohols form a broad peak around 3300 wavenumbers. It uses EM radiation of a longer wavelength than visible light.
This complex section of the IR spectroscopy readout between 500 and 1500 wavenumbers is very hard to read. Its name derives from the fact that this region gives a unique
This Caltech scientist and 1999 Nobel Prizewinner developed a form of IR spectroscopy which could image structures that only existed for femtoseconds at a time.
Name the play in which Michael Ransom tries to beat the fictional country of Ostnia to the title action.
he Ascent of F6 was written by Christopher Isherwood and this man, an Anglo-American also known for his poems "Funeral Blues" and "Musee des Beaux Arts."

This Auden poem centers on a deceased man who lived an ordinary life and against whom there was no complaint. It asks "Was he happy? The question is absurd:/ Had anything been wrong, we should certainly have heard."

Identify this Greek philosopher, who argued in his Politics that monarchs can only rule if they're more virtuous than all their citizens put together. He also authored the Poetics, Metaphysics, and Nichomachean Ethics.

Aristotle founded this group of philosophers, which included the historian Eudemos of Rhodes, Phanias of Eresus, and Theophrastus. It got its name from the fact that its members walked around while philosophizing.

This medieval philosopher wrote a famous commentary on Aristotle's categories. This scholasticist also wrote A Treatise on God as the First Principle and inspired many of the views of William of Ockham.
Identify this idea which held that each state should be allowed to decide, on its own, whether it's a free state or a slave state. It was also heavily promoted by Lewis Cass.

Popular sovereignty would have been superseded by this proposal, which would ban slavery in the territory acquired during the Mexican-American war. It was initially introduced as a rider to an appropriations bill.

The slavery issue divided the New York Democratic Party into the radical anti-slavery Barnburners and this opposing faction. This faction was further divided on whether to reconcile with the Barnburners.
Name this Pillar of Islam which commands those who have money above 20 gold mithqals or 200 silver dirhams to give alms to the poor in the community.
In addition to Zakat, Muslims may give this additional voluntary charitable contribution. A Hadith says that this "extinguishes sin as water extinguishes fire."
Riba is the Islamic name for this practice which is defined in Islam as charging any interest at all on a loan, as compared to other cultures which use it to refer only to excessive interest rates.

answers: Sonata No. 14 in C-sharp minor or "Moonlight" Sonata
Sonata No. 21 in C major or "Waldstein"
parts: Subtitled "Quasi una fantasia," this Beethoven sonata was compared to a night on Lake Lucerne by poet Ludwig Rellstab. Unusually for classical-period sonatas, it has a slow first movement and holds off on fast motion until the closing "Presto agitato."
ften named for the count to whom it was dedicated, this middle-period Beethoven sonata opens with a pulsating eighth-note rhythm in the bass.

This last Beethoven sonata is in only two movements and shares the stormy character of his other C minor works. Sergei Prokofiev modeled his second symphony after this work, whose second movement is an "Arietta." Sorry, no nicknames here!

answers: Catherine II of Russia or Catherine the Great [accept Yekaterina II Velikaya or Katharina die Grosse]
Pale of Settlement or cherta osedlosti
parts: Name this ruler who had many lovers including the last king of Poland, Stanislaw Poniatowski and Grigoriy Potemkin, who oversaw Russia's expansion into the Crimea during her reign.

This artillery commander and lover of Catherine organized the coup that overthrew Paul III. This first leader of the Free Economic Society later gave a namesake diamond to Catherine to try and win her back.

Shetls were communities in this area set up by Catherine in 1791 to appease the merchant classes. Its designated inhabitants were generally unable to live outside this area and were often subject to pogroms.
Identify this biochemical cycle which takes place within the matrix of the mitochondrion, named for a German.
The matrix of the mitochondrion is surrounded by a heavily folded inner membrane. Those folds and the compartments they form are given this name
This iron-sulfur containing enzyme in the Krebs cycle is responsible for the conversion of citrate to isocitrate.
Name this story mostly set at Kate and Julia Morkan's Christmas party, where Gabriel Conroy gives a traditional toast.
The Dead appears in James Joyce's Dubliners along with this story, named for the bazaar where the unnamed narrator goes to buy a gift for Mangan's sister.
The protagonists from this story also appear in the "Aeolus", "Sirens", and "Oxen of the Sun" episodes in Ulysses.  It centers on Lenehan and Corley deceiving a maid.

answers: Suleiman the Magnificent (or Suleiman I or Suleiman the Lawgiver)
parts: Name this 1529 event that resulted in the end of the Ottoman expansion into central Europe.
This leader of the Ottomans during the Siege of Vienna oversaw the Golden Age of the Ottoman Empire and married Roxelana, a harem girl.
This highly-influential vizier of Suleiman the Magnificent was a commander during the Siege of Vienna and was later executed for, among other things, adopting the title Serasker Sultan.
That limit is typically estimated using this formula developed by an English Lord which is given by the arcsine of 1.22 times the wavelength of the light divided by the diameter of the lens aperture.

The main reason for the Rayleigh Criterion limit is this phenomenon where waves bend around obstacles like double slits and interfere with each other. Patterns can be produced by its namesake gratings.

In terms of diffraction, the Rayleigh Criterion can be thought of as the angular distance at which these entities from waves at opposite sides of an object intersect. These arrays of concentric circles result from the diffraction created by the circular aperture of the telescope.

answers: To Damascus [or The Road to Damascus]
parts: Name this play in which Agnes, the daughter of Indra, descends to Earth and returns to heaven at the end.
This Swedish author of A Dream Play also wrote about the valet Jean who gives a razor to the title character of another play, Miss Julie.
Strindberg also wrote this trilogy in which the protagonist, known only as The Stranger, encounters various archetypal characters including The Confessor and The Tempter.

answers: Curling [Prompt on "That damn thing with the brooms"]
parts: Name this Olympic sport which features a thrower, 2 sweepers and a skip trying to land their shots as close to the button as possible. It called "Chess on Ice" for its high level of strategy.
Surrounding the button are 3 concentric circles that are red, white, and blue and located at 4, 8, and 12 feet respectively. That area in which rocks must land  to score is known by this term.
n order to enable the curling action and to reduce friction of the rocks on the ice, this layering of dots of water is performed on the ice.
Identify this field which was transformed by the minimalist program of Noam Chomsky. Semantics, stylistics, and semiotics are subfields within it.
Bally and Sechehaye compiled this man's notes into an important early text in linguistics. This man also studied laryngeal consonants in proto-Indo-European.

Sassure's Course in General Lingustics introduced these two components of language, one which describes the impersonal, ideal structure of words and sounds, while the other describes the actual use of language. Name both.

Identify this room in the home of Frederick Leyland which contains a lot of gold leaf paintings. It gets its name from a painting in it which features a pair of creatures fighting while holding a bag of money and a paintbrush.

The Peacock Room was painted and decorated by this American artist, who also depicted the Old Battersea Bridge in one of his Nocturnes, and whose Arrangement in Grey and Black, No. 1, depicts his mother.

The Peacock Room was eventually acquired by the Freer Gallery of Art, which is part of this family of museums. This family includes the Arts and Industries Building and the Hirschorn Sculpture Garden.
Name this empire whose first emperor was Sunni Ali, who conquered the remnants of the Mali Empire, and gained vast wealth through control of trade cities such as Timbuktu.
This city in modern day Mali originally lent its name to a powerful West African kingdom and later became the capital of the Songhai Empire.
The defeat of the Songhai by the Sultanate of Morocco at this battle led to the downfall of the Empire and was due in part to the gunpowder weapons of the Moroccan forces.

answers: Eagle or Sun? or Aguila o sol?
parts: Name this poem better known for having 584 lines to match up with the 584 days of the Aztec calendar.
This Mexican poet wrote "Sunstone" as well as the nine-part collection of essays, The Labyrinth of Solitude.
This first collection of Paz's poetry includes "The Blue Bouquet" and the title poem, which states that Today I fight alone with a word" and compares the title two things to heads or tails of a coin.
Identify this conflict detailed in the Homeric epic the Iliad, in which one side used a large wooden horse to sneak into the city walls.

This queen of the Amazons led a force of 12 other warriors with the express purpose of killing Achilles during the Trojan War. Achilles fell in love with her and supposedly had sex with her corpse after he killed her.
This son of Iphicles was the first person to step onto the soil at Troy, and thus fated to be the first to die. His wife Laodamia jumped into a fire with a bronze statue of him in devotion.

These events, the most recent of which, at about 1.2 million years ago, saw a transition from the Matuyama to the Brunhes Chron. These events have been hypothesized to be the cause of several mass extinctions.
This triply eponymous hypothesis predicted that the Magnetic pole reversals would leave symmetric traces in rocks that were forming in Mid Ocean Ridges.

The Vine Matthews Morley Hypothesis was used to test this theory proposed by Harry Hess. This subset of Plate tectonics is the expansion of oceans by the production of new oceanic crust at mid ocean ridges.
